abstract: Create text that expands out of a window using stacked SwiftUI text views.
overview:
## Overview

This sample app demonstrates how to stack multiple text views so the text appears to pop out of its window. At launch, the app applies a spring animation to the views in the stack, causing the text to pop out, like the scene in the following image:

### Initialize the text

The app’s `DepthTextView` creates and stores a [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/Text] instance as one of its properties:

By passing [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/Font/extraLargeTitle] to the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/Text/font(_:)] modifier, it makes the text appear bigger. The main view creates text variations from this property in its methods and computed properties.

### Create the foremost text view

The `textFrontView` property creates a variation of the `text` property, to act as the view that pops out the most, by changing its offset along the z-axis:

The sample achieves this by passing the largest value into the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/View/offset(z:)] modifier. The offset value, excluding the `animationProgress` value that controls the animation, is the product of the `layerSpacing` and `layers` properties:

### Generate a series of text layers along the z-axis

The `textMiddleViews` property makes several variations of the `text` property to form the middle layers between the shadow and the front of the stack. It does this by creating a [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/ForEach] instance to generate the text views:

The property dynamically applies a unique offset along the z-axis to each text view by passing a larger value to the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/View/offset(z:)] modifier with each iteration. This offset creates a stacking effect that shows the text extending outward from the view window.

The `layers` property controls the number of iterations:

### Generate a shadow version of the text view

The `textShadowView` property makes a version of the `text` property that acts as a shadow by adding a blur effect and modifying its style and transparency:

The [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/View/blur(radius:opaque:)] view modifier applies a Gaussian blur to the text view, and the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/Color/opacity(_:)] view modifier makes the view semitransparent.

### Stack the text with animations

The `DepthTextView` arranges its view properties along its z-axis by adding a [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/ZStack] as the main view of its `body` property:

The `textShadowView`, `textMiddleViews`, and `textFrontView` properties each create a version of the text. The sample adds an animation effect to its [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/ZStack] by passing its `animateWithSpringEffect` method to the stack’s [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/SwiftUI/View/onAppear(perform:)] view modifier.

The `animateWithSpringEffect` method animates the transition through the `animationProgress` property from `0.0` to `1.0` by:

The `animateWithSpringEffect()` method creates a spring animation with `stiffness` and `damping` properties, as well as a one-second delay. It animates the `animationProgress` from 0.0 to 1.0, resulting in a springlike pop effect as the text enters the view.
